article_title: List of FC Barcelona records and statistics

msg.content:
<document>
<title>List of FC Barcelona records and statistics</title>
<content>
Barcelona Statistics at large





![](image)Lionel Messi, pictured in 2018, is Barcelona's all-time top scorer, with 672 goals in all competitions.[1]
Futbol Club Barcelona is a professional association football club based in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. Founded by a group of Swiss, German, English and Catalan footballers led by Joan Gamper, the club has become a symbol of Catalan culture and Catalanism, hence the motto *"Ms que un club"* (More than a club). The official Bara anthem is the "Cant del Bara", written by Jaume Picas and Josep Maria Espins.[2] Unlike many other football clubs, the *socis*, who are the members and supporters of the club, own and operate Barcelona. It is the world's fourth richest football club in terms of revenue, with an annual turnover of 582.1 million in the 202021 season.[3]


Barcelona played its first friendly match on 8 December 1899 against the English colony in Barcelona in the old velodrome in Bonanova.[4] Initially, Barcelona played against other local clubs in various Catalan tournaments. In 1929, the club became one of the founding members of La Liga, Spain's first national league, and has since achieved the distinction of being one of only three clubs to have never been relegated, along with Real Madrid and Athletic Bilbao. Barcelona is also the only European club to have played continental football every season since 1955. They hold a long-standing rivalry with Real Madrid, with matches between the two teams referred to as "El Clsico" (*El Clssic* in Catalan). Matches against city rivals Espanyol are known as the "Derbi barcelon".


Barcelona has amassed various records in regional, domestic and continental tournaments since its founding. During the time the club played in regional competitions until the end of the Catalan championship in 1940, it won a record 23 titles from a possible 38. In 2009, Barcelona achieved an unprecedented sextuple by winning La Liga, the Copa del Rey, the UEFA Champions League, the Supercopa de Espaa, the UEFA Super Cup and the FIFA Club World Cup in one calendar year. Additionally, Bara has won the coveted continental treble, consisting of La Liga, the Copa del Rey and the UEFA Champions League in the aforementioned 2009 and again 2015, becoming the first European club to have won the treble twice.[5]


Barcelona has signed several high-profile players, setting the world record in transfer fees on three occasions with the purchase of Johan Cruyff from Ajax in 1973, Diego Maradona from Boca Juniors in 1982 and Ronaldo from PSV Eindhoven in 1996. The club's players have received seven FIFA World Player of the Year awards, twelve Ballon d'Or awards, three UEFA Men's Player of the Year awards and eight European Golden Shoe awards.




## Honours[edit]


FC Barcelona won their first trophy in 1902 when they lifted the Copa Macaya, which was the predecessor to the Catalan Championship. The club won the Catalan Championship a record 23 times during the 40-year span of the tournament.[6]


When the national league was established in 1929, the importance of the regional league declined, and it was abandoned in 1940. From then on, Barcelona did not participate in regional competitions until the establishment of the Copa Catalunya in 1993, a cup they have won a record nine times.[6]


They are the most successful football club in Spain, having won a total of 77 domestic titles: 27 La Liga, a record 31 Copa del Rey, a record 14 Supercopa de Espaa, a record three Copa Eva Duarte[note 1] and a record two Copa de la Liga.


The club is also one of the most successful clubs in international club football, having won 22 official trophies in total, 14 of which are UEFA competitions and 8 recognised by FIFA. Barcelona has won five UEFA Champions League titles, a record four UEFA Cup Winners' Cup titles, a record three Inter-Cities Fairs Cup titles (non-UEFA), a shared record of two Latin Cup titles, a shared record of five UEFA Super Cup titles and three FIFA Club World Cup titles. They are also second to Real Madrid in terms of overall official titles 99-101.[7][8]

* The following Barcelona players have won the Ricardo Zamora Trophy for lowest "goals-to-games" ratio in La Liga (Antoni Ramallets and Vctor Valds have each won the trophy a record five times for Barcelona):[1]
	+ ![Spain](image) Juan Zambudio Velasco: (1) 194748
	+ ![Spain](image) Antoni Ramallets: (5) 195152, 195556, 195657, 195859, 195960
	+ ![Spain](image) Jos Manuel Pesudo: (1) 196566
	+ ![Spain](image) Salvador Sadurn: (3) 196869, 197374, 197475
	+ ![Spain](image) Miguel Reina: (1) 197273
	+ ![Spain](image) Pedro Mara Artola: (1) 197778
	+ ![Spain](image) Javier Urruticoechea: (1) 198384
	+ ![Spain](image) Andoni Zubizarreta: (1) 198687
	+ ![Spain](image) Vctor Valds: (5) 200405, 200809, 200910, 201011, 201112
	+ ![Chile](image) Claudio Bravo: (1) 201415
	+ ![Germany](image) Marc-Andr ter Stegen: (1) 202223
* Longest period without conceding a goal:[1]
	+ ![Spain](image) Vctor Valds went 896 minutes without conceding a goal in all competitions in the 201112 season (from the 22nd minute of the 5th game to the 20th minute of the 12th game). Six games of the Spanish League and three Champions League games were played without conceding a goal.
	+ ![Spain](image) Miguel Reina went 824 minutes without conceding a goal in the Spanish League in the 197273 season (from the 53rd minute of the 14th game to the 67th minute of the 23rd game).
* Most clean sheets:
	+ ![Spain](image) Vctor Valds played 535 official games of which he maintained a clean sheet in 237 games, or 44.3% of the matches. The former record was held by ![Spain](image) Andoni Zubizarreta who played 410 official games of which he maintained a clean sheet in 173 games, or 42.2% of the matches.
* Most clean sheets in a season:[74]
	+ **33** in 201415: **23** kept by ![Chile](image) Claudio Bravo (all in La Liga), **10** kept by ![Germany](image) Marc-Andr ter Stegen **6** in Champions League and **4** in Copa del Rey.
* Most clean sheets registered by a keeper in a La Liga season:[75]
	+ **26** kept by ![Germany](image) Marc-Andr ter Stegen in 202223.
* Goalkeeper with best average goals conceded in history:[75]
	+ ![Germany](image) Marc-Andr ter Stegen in 202223 with an average of **0.47** goals (**18** goals in **38** games).
* Best unbeaten start:[76]
	+ **754** minutes by ![Chile](image) Claudio Bravo in 201415.

## Managerial records[edit]


See also: List of FC Barcelona managers

* First full-time manager: ![England](image) John Barrow.[89]
* Most seasons as coach: ![England](image) Jack Greenwell, nine years in two spells from 1917 to 1924 and from 1931 to 1933.[1]
* Most consecutive seasons as coach: ![Netherlands](image) Johan Cruyff, managed the club for eight years between 1988 and 1996.[1]
* Most matches undefeated in a La Liga season: **37** ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola in 200910 season and ![Spain](image) Ernesto Valverde in 201718 season[1]
* Most consecutive matches undefeated in a La Liga season: **36** ![Spain](image) Ernesto Valverde, between Matchdays 1 and 34 (matchday 34 was played after matchday 36) in 201718 season[1]
* Most consecutive away matches undefeated in a La Liga season: **16** ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola, between 29 August 2010 (Matchday 1) and 23 April 2011 (Matchday 33) in 201011 season[1]
* Most consecutive away matches won in La Liga: **10** ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola, between 29 August 2010 (Matchday 1) and 29 January 2011 (Matchday 21) in 2010-11 season[1]
* Most trophies won as coach: ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola, 14 titles out of 19 possible between August 2008 and May 2012.[1]
* Coaches who won the treble:[90]
	+ ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola in 200809.
	+ ![Spain](image) Luis Enrique in 201415.

	+ **55** points during the 201213 season (La Liga record).
* The team with most points at the end of the second half of the league:[91]
	+ **50** points during the 200910 season.
* Maximum difference over the runner up:[93]
	+ **15** points over Real Madrid in the 201213 season (La Liga record).


#### Goals[edit]

	+ +89 in 201415 season.[91][95]

	+ In 201617 season, the club scored a total number of 116 goals in 38 games.[91][94]

	+ The club scored a total number of 32 goals in 22 games in the 193940 season.[91][96]

	+ The club conceded a total number of 18 goals in 30 games in the 196869 season.[91][98]

* Season with most goals conceded:
	+ The club conceded a total number of 66 goals in 26 games in the 194142 season.[91][99]

	+ 180 goals in 2015

### International[edit]


* Only team to have appeared in every year of the continental competition:[91]
	+ Barcelona has participated since the inception in 1955.
* Highest win in European competitions at home games:[91]
	+ **80** over Apollon Limassol (Cyprus) in 1982 and 80 over Pchov (Slovakia) in 2003.
* Highest win in European competition at away games:[91]
	+ **07** over Hapoel Be'er Sheva (Israel) in the 199596 UEFA Cup.
* Most consecutive wins in the UEFA Champions League:[91]
	+ **11** wins during the 200203 season.
* Most goals in a UEFA Champions League season:[91]
	+ **45** goals during the 19992000 season.
* Most FIFA World Cup Golden Balls won by the players from a single club:
	+ **4** ![Netherlands](image) Johan Cruyff won in 1974, ![Brazil](image) Romrio in 1994, and ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi in 2014 and 2022.
* Most FIFA Club World Cup Golden Balls won by the players from a single club:
	+ **4** Deco (won in 2006), ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi (won in 2009 and 2011), and ![Uruguay](image) Luis Surez (won in 2015).
* Most FIFA/France Football Ballons d'Or won by the players from a single club:[78]
	+ **12** ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi (won in 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2015 and 2019), ![Netherlands](image) Johan Cruyff (won in 1973 and 1974), ![Spain](image) Luis Surez (won in 1960), ![Bulgaria](image) Hristo Stoichkov (won in 1994), ![Brazil](image) Rivaldo (won in 1999), and ![Brazil](image) Ronaldinho (won in 2005).
* Most European Golden Shoe awards won by the players from a single club:
	+ **8** ![Brazil](image) Ronaldo (won in 1997), ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi (won in 2010, 2012, 2013, 2017, 2018 and 2019), and ![Uruguay](image) Luis Surez (won in 2016).
* Only team that have been represented by final three contenders at a FIFA Ballon d'Or Gala:
	+ In **2010**, the final three contenders were Barcelona players ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi, ![Spain](image) Andrs Iniesta and ![Spain](image) Xavi.
* Only team of which youth academy has been represented by final three contenders at a FIFA Ballon d'Or Gala:
	+ In **2010**, the final three contenders were Barcelona youth academy players ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi, ![Spain](image) Andrs Iniesta and ![Spain](image) Xavi.
* Only team that have collected all the awards (Golden Boot, Golden Ball, Silver Ball, Bronze Ball and Fair Play award) at a single FIFA Club World Cup:[104]
	+ In **2015**, ![Uruguay](image) Luis Surez won the Golden Ball and the Golden Boot, ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi won the Silver Ball, ![Spain](image) Andrs Iniesta won the Bronze Ball and Barcelona was awarded the Fair Play award.

* Team with most Spanish titles: **109**.[91]
* Spanish club with most official titles: **124**.[91]

	+ Five championship titles in 195152: La Liga, Copa del Rey, the Latin Cup, Copa Eva Duarte and Copa Martini & Rossi.

	+ **180**, in the Copa Macaya: Tarragona 018 Barcelona in 1901.
* Biggest win in a Friendly match:[91]
	+ **201**, Smilde (Netherlands) 120 Barcelona in 1992.
* Longest unbeaten run in all competitive matches:[108]
	+ **39** games in the 201516 season
* Longest winning run in competitive matches:[91]
	+ **19** games in both domestic and international matches during the 200506 season: 13 in the league, 3 in the Champions League, 2 in the Spanish cup and 1 in the Catalan Cup.
* Most consecutive away wins:[91]
	+ **13** games during the 200809 season: 8 in the league, 3 in the Champions League and 2 in the Copa del Rey (also a Spanish football record).
* Longest scoring run in all competitions:[92]
	+ **44** games: **36** in league between game 9 (22 November 1942) of the 194243 season and game 18 (6 February 1944) of the 194344 season, and **8** Cup games in 1943.
* 2nd most goals in a season  all competitions:[1]
	+ **190** in the 201112
* Most goals scored by players from the youth system:[1]
	+ Of the **190** goals scored in the 201112 season, **150** were scored by players from Barcelona's youth system (also a Spanish football record).
* Most scorers in official matches in a season:[1]
	+ In the 201011 season, **23** Barcelona players scored at least one goal in official competitions (also a Spanish football record).
* Most victories in a season:[74]
	+ **50** in the 201415 season, out of a possible 60 games (also a Spanish Football record).
* Most matches unbeaten by a Spanish team  all competitions:[1]
	+ **34** in the 201516 season
* Most consecutive away wins:[74]
	+ **13** games during the 200809 season.

<title>List of FC Barcelona records and statistics</title>
<content>
Barcelona Statistics at large





![](image)Lionel Messi, pictured in 2018, is Barcelona's all-time top scorer, with 672 goals in all competitions.[1]
Futbol Club Barcelona is a professional association football club based in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. Founded by a group of Swiss, German, English and Catalan footballers led by Joan Gamper, the club has become a symbol of Catalan culture and Catalanism, hence the motto *"Ms que un club"* (More than a club). The official Bara anthem is the "Cant del Bara", written by Jaume Picas and Josep Maria Espins.[2] Unlike many other football clubs, the *socis*, who are the members and supporters of the club, own and operate Barcelona. It is the world's fourth richest football club in terms of revenue, with an annual turnover of 582.1 million in the 202021 season.[3]


Barcelona played its first friendly match on 8 December 1899 against the English colony in Barcelona in the old velodrome in Bonanova.[4] Initially, Barcelona played against other local clubs in various Catalan tournaments. In 1929, the club became one of the founding members of La Liga, Spain's first national league, and has since achieved the distinction of being one of only three clubs to have never been relegated, along with Real Madrid and Athletic Bilbao. Barcelona is also the only European club to have played continental football every season since 1955. They hold a long-standing rivalry with Real Madrid, with matches between the two teams referred to as "El Clsico" (*El Clssic* in Catalan). Matches against city rivals Espanyol are known as the "Derbi barcelon".


Barcelona has amassed various records in regional, domestic and continental tournaments since its founding. During the time the club played in regional competitions until the end of the Catalan championship in 1940, it won a record 23 titles from a possible 38. In 2009, Barcelona achieved an unprecedented sextuple by winning La Liga, the Copa del Rey, the UEFA Champions League, the Supercopa de Espaa, the UEFA Super Cup and the FIFA Club World Cup in one calendar year. Additionally, Bara has won the coveted continental treble, consisting of La Liga, the Copa del Rey and the UEFA Champions League in the aforementioned 2009 and again 2015, becoming the first European club to have won the treble twice.[5]


Barcelona has signed several high-profile players, setting the world record in transfer fees on three occasions with the purchase of Johan Cruyff from Ajax in 1973, Diego Maradona from Boca Juniors in 1982 and Ronaldo from PSV Eindhoven in 1996. The club's players have received seven FIFA World Player of the Year awards, twelve Ballon d'Or awards, three UEFA Men's Player of the Year awards and eight European Golden Shoe awards.




## Honours[edit]


FC Barcelona won their first trophy in 1902 when they lifted the Copa Macaya, which was the predecessor to the Catalan Championship. The club won the Catalan Championship a record 23 times during the 40-year span of the tournament.[6]


When the national league was established in 1929, the importance of the regional league declined, and it was abandoned in 1940. From then on, Barcelona did not participate in regional competitions until the establishment of the Copa Catalunya in 1993, a cup they have won a record nine times.[6]


They are the most successful football club in Spain, having won a total of 77 domestic titles: 27 La Liga, a record 31 Copa del Rey, a record 14 Supercopa de Espaa, a record three Copa Eva Duarte[note 1] and a record two Copa de la Liga.


The club is also one of the most successful clubs in international club football, having won 22 official trophies in total, 14 of which are UEFA competitions and 8 recognised by FIFA. Barcelona has won five UEFA Champions League titles, a record four UEFA Cup Winners' Cup titles, a record three Inter-Cities Fairs Cup titles (non-UEFA), a shared record of two Latin Cup titles, a shared record of five UEFA Super Cup titles and three FIFA Club World Cup titles. They are also second to Real Madrid in terms of overall official titles 99-101.[7][8]

* The following Barcelona players have won the Ricardo Zamora Trophy for lowest "goals-to-games" ratio in La Liga (Antoni Ramallets and Vctor Valds have each won the trophy a record five times for Barcelona):[1]
	+ ![Spain](image) Juan Zambudio Velasco: (1) 194748
	+ ![Spain](image) Antoni Ramallets: (5) 195152, 195556, 195657, 195859, 195960
	+ ![Spain](image) Jos Manuel Pesudo: (1) 196566
	+ ![Spain](image) Salvador Sadurn: (3) 196869, 197374, 197475
	+ ![Spain](image) Miguel Reina: (1) 197273
	+ ![Spain](image) Pedro Mara Artola: (1) 197778
	+ ![Spain](image) Javier Urruticoechea: (1) 198384
	+ ![Spain](image) Andoni Zubizarreta: (1) 198687
	+ ![Spain](image) Vctor Valds: (5) 200405, 200809, 200910, 201011, 201112
	+ ![Chile](image) Claudio Bravo: (1) 201415
	+ ![Germany](image) Marc-Andr ter Stegen: (1) 202223
* Longest period without conceding a goal:[1]
	+ ![Spain](image) Vctor Valds went 896 minutes without conceding a goal in all competitions in the 201112 season (from the 22nd minute of the 5th game to the 20th minute of the 12th game). Six games of the Spanish League and three Champions League games were played without conceding a goal.
	+ ![Spain](image) Miguel Reina went 824 minutes without conceding a goal in the Spanish League in the 197273 season (from the 53rd minute of the 14th game to the 67th minute of the 23rd game).
* Most clean sheets:
	+ ![Spain](image) Vctor Valds played 535 official games of which he maintained a clean sheet in 237 games, or 44.3% of the matches. The former record was held by ![Spain](image) Andoni Zubizarreta who played 410 official games of which he maintained a clean sheet in 173 games, or 42.2% of the matches.
* Most clean sheets in a season:[74]
	+ **33** in 201415: **23** kept by ![Chile](image) Claudio Bravo (all in La Liga), **10** kept by ![Germany](image) Marc-Andr ter Stegen **6** in Champions League and **4** in Copa del Rey.
* Most clean sheets registered by a keeper in a La Liga season:[75]
	+ **26** kept by ![Germany](image) Marc-Andr ter Stegen in 202223.
* Goalkeeper with best average goals conceded in history:[75]
	+ ![Germany](image) Marc-Andr ter Stegen in 202223 with an average of **0.47** goals (**18** goals in **38** games).
* Best unbeaten start:[76]
	+ **754** minutes by ![Chile](image) Claudio Bravo in 201415.

## Managerial records[edit]


See also: List of FC Barcelona managers

* First full-time manager: ![England](image) John Barrow.[89]
* Most seasons as coach: ![England](image) Jack Greenwell, nine years in two spells from 1917 to 1924 and from 1931 to 1933.[1]
* Most consecutive seasons as coach: ![Netherlands](image) Johan Cruyff, managed the club for eight years between 1988 and 1996.[1]
* Most matches undefeated in a La Liga season: **37** ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola in 200910 season and ![Spain](image) Ernesto Valverde in 201718 season[1]
* Most consecutive matches undefeated in a La Liga season: **36** ![Spain](image) Ernesto Valverde, between Matchdays 1 and 34 (matchday 34 was played after matchday 36) in 201718 season[1]
* Most consecutive away matches undefeated in a La Liga season: **16** ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola, between 29 August 2010 (Matchday 1) and 23 April 2011 (Matchday 33) in 201011 season[1]
* Most consecutive away matches won in La Liga: **10** ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola, between 29 August 2010 (Matchday 1) and 29 January 2011 (Matchday 21) in 2010-11 season[1]
* Most trophies won as coach: ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola, 14 titles out of 19 possible between August 2008 and May 2012.[1]
* Coaches who won the treble:[90]
	+ ![Spain](image) Pep Guardiola in 200809.
	+ ![Spain](image) Luis Enrique in 201415.

	+ **50** points during the 200910 season.

### International[edit]


* Only team to have appeared in every year of the continental competition:[91]

	+ **07** over Hapoel Be'er Sheva (Israel) in the 199596 UEFA Cup.
* Most consecutive wins in the UEFA Champions League:[91]
	+ **11** wins during the 200203 season.
* Most goals in a UEFA Champions League season:[91]
	+ **45** goals during the 19992000 season.
* Most FIFA World Cup Golden Balls won by the players from a single club:
	+ **4** ![Netherlands](image) Johan Cruyff won in 1974, ![Brazil](image) Romrio in 1994, and ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi in 2014 and 2022.
* Most FIFA Club World Cup Golden Balls won by the players from a single club:
	+ **4** Deco (won in 2006), ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi (won in 2009 and 2011), and ![Uruguay](image) Luis Surez (won in 2015).
* Most FIFA/France Football Ballons d'Or won by the players from a single club:[78]
	+ **12** ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi (won in 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2015 and 2019), ![Netherlands](image) Johan Cruyff (won in 1973 and 1974), ![Spain](image) Luis Surez (won in 1960), ![Bulgaria](image) Hristo Stoichkov (won in 1994), ![Brazil](image) Rivaldo (won in 1999), and ![Brazil](image) Ronaldinho (won in 2005).
* Most European Golden Shoe awards won by the players from a single club:
	+ **8** ![Brazil](image) Ronaldo (won in 1997), ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi (won in 2010, 2012, 2013, 2017, 2018 and 2019), and ![Uruguay](image) Luis Surez (won in 2016).
* Only team that have been represented by final three contenders at a FIFA Ballon d'Or Gala:
	+ In **2010**, the final three contenders were Barcelona players ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi, ![Spain](image) Andrs Iniesta and ![Spain](image) Xavi.
* Only team of which youth academy has been represented by final three contenders at a FIFA Ballon d'Or Gala:
	+ In **2010**, the final three contenders were Barcelona youth academy players ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi, ![Spain](image) Andrs Iniesta and ![Spain](image) Xavi.

	+ In **2015**, ![Uruguay](image) Luis Surez won the Golden Ball and the Golden Boot, ![Argentina](image) Lionel Messi won the Silver Ball, ![Spain](image) Andrs Iniesta won the Bronze Ball and Barcelona was awarded the Fair Play award.

	+ **180**, in the Copa Macaya: Tarragona 018 Barcelona in 1901.

	+ **201**, Smilde (Netherlands) 120 Barcelona in 1992.
* Longest unbeaten run in all competitive matches:[108]
	+ **39** games in the 201516 season
* Longest winning run in competitive matches:[91]
	+ **19** games in both domestic and international matches during the 200506 season: 13 in the league, 3 in the Champions League, 2 in the Spanish cup and 1 in the Catalan Cup.
* Most consecutive away wins:[91]
	+ **13** games during the 200809 season: 8 in the league, 3 in the Champions League and 2 in the Copa del Rey (also a Spanish football record).

	+ **44** games: **36** in league between game 9 (22 November 1942) of the 194243 season and game 18 (6 February 1944) of the 194344 season, and **8** Cup games in 1943.
* 2nd most goals in a season  all competitions:[1]
	+ **190** in the 201112
* Most goals scored by players from the youth system:[1]
	+ Of the **190** goals scored in the 201112 season, **150** were scored by players from Barcelona's youth system (also a Spanish football record).
* Most scorers in official matches in a season:[1]
	+ In the 201011 season, **23** Barcelona players scored at least one goal in official competitions (also a Spanish football record).
* Most victories in a season:[74]
	+ **50** in the 201415 season, out of a possible 60 games (also a Spanish Football record).
* Most matches unbeaten by a Spanish team  all competitions:[1]
	+ **34** in the 201516 season
* Most consecutive away wins:[74]
	+ **13** games during the 200809 season.
